revisions:
[{'created': '2022-03-03 17:30:58.000000000', 'message': '[SR-IOV] Fix QoS extension to set min/max values

"ip link" commands allow to define VF rates independently.
That means, first "rate" (max BW) can be set and in a second
command "min" (min BW) (check LP bug description).

However Pyroute2 command to set the VF rates requires to set both.
If one value is missing ("min_tx_rate", "max_tx_rate"), the library
sets this value to 0; in other words, the value is deleted.

This patch reads first the existing rates ("min_tx_rate",
"max_tx_rate") and populates the command parameters accordingly.

Closes-Bug: #1962844
Change-Id: Ibbb6d938355440c42850812e368224b76b1fce19
'}, {'created': '2022-03-04 16:52:32.000000000', 'message': '[SR-IOV] Fix QoS extension to set min/max values

"ip link" commands allow to define VF rates independently.
That means, first "rate" (max BW) can be set and in a second
command "min" (min BW) (check LP bug description).

However Pyroute2 command to set the VF rates requires to set both.
If one value is missing ("min_tx_rate", "max_tx_rate"), the library
sets this value to 0; in other words, the value is deleted.

This patch reads first the existing rates ("min_tx_rate",
"max_tx_rate") and populates the command parameters accordingly.

Closes-Bug: #1962844
Change-Id: Ibbb6d938355440c42850812e368224b76b1fce19
'}, {'created': '2022-03-08 17:28:51.000000000', 'message': '[SR-IOV] Fix QoS extension to set min/max values

"ip link" commands allow to define VF rates independently.
That means, first "rate" (max BW) can be set and in a second
command "min" (min BW) (check LP bug description).

However Pyroute2 command to set the VF rates requires to set both.
If one value is missing ("min_tx_rate", "max_tx_rate"), the library
sets this value to 0; in other words, the value is deleted.

The Pyroute2 structures are built depending on the parameter names.
In this case, {'vf': {'rate': ...}} will create a "vf_rate" [1]
nla structure, that requires "min_tx_rate" and "max_tx_rate".
This is part of the full structure passed to the "iproute" library
[2].

This is an example of code that only sets the "max_tx_rate" for
the 15th VF of "enp196s0f0":
  $ from neutron.plugins.ml2.drivers.mech_sriov.agent import pci_lib
    pci = pci_lib.PciDeviceIPWrapper("enp196s0f0")
    pci.set_vf_rate(15, {'max_tx_rate': 10})

The "msg" [3] (structure passed to "iproute" library) is this:
https://paste.opendev.org/show/b2FZBOebGOCHMrYhPr6X/. The
"min_tx_rate" is set to the default value 0.

This patch reads first the existing rates ("min_tx_rate",
"max_tx_rate") and populates the command parameters accordingly.

[1]https://github.com/svinota/pyroute2/blob/a9564dff8e53659f761d71bbee0dd68dd0db6ce8/pyroute2.core/pr2modules/netlink/rtnl/ifinfmsg/__init__.py#L712-L717
[2]https://github.com/shemminger/iproute2/blob/c8d9d92544668922dc5aa06d2491f42b837b9361/ip/ipaddress.c#L454-L470
[3]https://github.com/svinota/pyroute2/blob/a9564dff8e53659f761d71bbee0dd68dd0db6ce8/pyroute2.core/pr2modules/iproute/linux.py#L1499

Closes-Bug: #1962844
Change-Id: Ibbb6d938355440c42850812e368224b76b1fce19
'}]
commit_message:
[SR-IOV] Fix QoS extension to set min/max values

"ip link" commands allow to define VF rates independently.
That means, first "rate" (max BW) can be set and in a second
command "min" (min BW) (check LP bug description).

However Pyroute2 command to set the VF rates requires to set both.
If one value is missing ("min_tx_rate", "max_tx_rate"), the library
sets this value to 0; in other words, the value is deleted.

The Pyroute2 structures are built depending on the parameter names.
In this case, {'vf': {'rate': ...}} will create a "vf_rate" [1]
nla structure, that requires "min_tx_rate" and "max_tx_rate".
This is part of the full structure passed to the "iproute" library
[2].

This is an example of code that only sets the "max_tx_rate" for
the 15th VF of "enp196s0f0":
  $ from neutron.plugins.ml2.drivers.mech_sriov.agent import pci_lib
    pci = pci_lib.PciDeviceIPWrapper("enp196s0f0")
    pci.set_vf_rate(15, {'max_tx_rate': 10})

The "msg" [3] (structure passed to "iproute" library) is this:
https://paste.opendev.org/show/b2FZBOebGOCHMrYhPr6X/. The
"min_tx_rate" is set to the default value 0.

This patch reads first the existing rates ("min_tx_rate",
"max_tx_rate") and populates the command parameters accordingly.

[1]https://github.com/svinota/pyroute2/blob/a9564dff8e53659f761d71bbee0dd68dd0db6ce8/pyroute2.core/pr2modules/netlink/rtnl/ifinfmsg/__init__.py#L712-L717
[2]https://github.com/shemminger/iproute2/blob/c8d9d92544668922dc5aa06d2491f42b837b9361/ip/ipaddress.c#L454-L470
[3]https://github.com/svinota/pyroute2/blob/a9564dff8e53659f761d71bbee0dd68dd0db6ce8/pyroute2.core/pr2modules/iproute/linux.py#L1499

Closes-Bug: #1962844
Change-Id: Ibbb6d938355440c42850812e368224b76b1fce19

commit_message:
Fix context unit test

This was caused by the bump of oslo.context to 4.1.0 [1], which includes
removal of the deprecated argument tenant from RequestContext [2].

Replace tenant key in the context object by project_id to fix the lower
constraints job, which is still using oslo.context 2.22.0.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/requirements/+/829599
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/oslo.context/+/815938

Change-Id: I281ffa4f6fc29c691da48a792bc203818e334d9d
(cherry picked from commit 8af178c38fa2510fc4da726e1b7ac578b4a3070f)

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/xena

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/xena branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I9c80e76e01474f996b37d6fe118384fc99d58b11

commit_message:
Add schema for compute 2.45 microversion

Compute microversion 2.45 changed the response
of create image and create backup APIs.

create image schema already covered
- https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/fec2c93cdcc14ad08d0a35136ee287525e7a4879/tempest/lib/api_schema/response/compute/v2_45/images.py

This patch adds the schema for create backup API.

Partially Implements: blueprint fix-microversion-gap

Change-Id: Icfeec8957c58472e7f176680d48745b5c5350b55

commit_message:
Fix lower-constraints job

This patch updates some packages version in lower-contraints.txt
to fix lower-constraint job. It also drops some linter from
lower-constraints.txt as not required for lower-constraints job.

Change-Id: If62522f716ae589d3b227ecdd1ea156090ca887a
(cherry picked from commit 157a343e802d81a461790868c2e34ca803fff92c)

commit_message:
Support binding floating ip to smart-nic port

When the Ironic use smart NICs to implement Bare Metal servers, the
neutron L2 agent and L3 agent run locally on the smart NIC. The
smart-nic port can be bound to the virtual bridge, and the floating
ip can also be implemented by the L3 agent on the smart NIC.

Closes-Bug: #1962821
Change-Id: I6c10c51b4ed6fd5f05671a9d3b2d5d7aa087eb2b

commit_message:
Fix the wrong [quota] parameters

The change a37c1416ac7df0ff90020a0c9dbf46b1a3095984 updated quota
parameters to use the new [quota] section but the change didn't remove
the 'quota_' prefix from parameters.

This change removes the prefix to fix the ineffective parameters.

Change-Id: I1744ed26caa760ea1f85aabe5b465afb4253e294
Closes-Bug: #1963855
(cherry picked from commit fc82186320806adfe78dd5692a6b7d2bd9b7cc83)

subject: Improve LB deletion reliability
revisions:
[{'created': '2022-03-03 14:03:39.000000000', 'message': 'Improve LB deletion reliability

When deleting a Octavia LB, it is often
necessary to use the --cascade option.

Since all related objects should be deleted
prior to removing the LB. I believe we should
include this option by default.

Resolves: rhbz#2060338

commit_message:
Improve LB deletion reliability

When deleting a Octavia LB, it is often
necessary to use the --cascade option.

Since all related objects should be deleted
prior to removing the LB. I believe we should
include this option by default.

Resolves: rhbz#2060338
Change-Id: I2581658e34eef2ee47da019169eee3b02a584df8

commit_message:
Telemetry: Switch back to launchpad from storyboard

Telemetry project decided to use launchpad again to manage bugs and
no longer relies on storyboard. This removes use-storyboard tag from
Telemetry projects so that automation is executed against launchpad
bugs correctly.

Change-Id: Id006c9e05073675a67274e5b00b89479bf124e32

commit_message:
Fix trailing slashes in bind-mounts and linting

Podman is not always happy with bind-mounts ending
with / (See I094120f7f2f6bfcfc0cc5843aa1b23629cd90a23)

Follow up If951f9643d67574c1225301aab7c9e4b0d316b7f
with that YAML linter couldn't catch.

Improve linter to process all volumes in templates, including
common/logging services templates, and neither puppet, not ansible
ones, like deployment/deprecated/multipathd-container.yaml.

Change-Id: Ia517b34c9d633101502bd8788e7b8764e75bbe64
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2022-03-07 14:46:07.000000000', 'message': 'Add role tripleo-ci-post

Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ibae7eaa6e6e91c88ac233c8fd52550e89bf2defc
'}, {'created': '2022-03-07 14:47:38.000000000', 'message': 'Add role tripleo-ci-post

Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ibae7eaa6e6e91c88ac233c8fd52550e89bf2defc
'}, {'created': '2022-03-07 15:21:33.000000000', 'message': 'Add role tripleo-ci-post

playbooks/tripleo-ci/post-artifact-mult.yml and
playbooks/tripleo-ci/post-artifact-sa.yml are used in post-run
to collect zuul artifacts.

Both are defined in multinode and standalone CentOS 8 base jobs.

While doing Zuul job reparenting, We found that It cannot be used
in different jobs defined in downstream or RDO. As zuul looks for
playbook in the project where zuul jobs are defined.

In order to reuse it in downstream and RDO, we are converting it
into role and call it in starting as a part of post.yaml playbook.

Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ibae7eaa6e6e91c88ac233c8fd52550e89bf2defc
'}, {'created': '2022-03-07 15:25:54.000000000', 'message': 'Added tripleo-ci-post ansible role

playbooks/tripleo-ci/post-artifact-mult.yml and
playbooks/tripleo-ci/post-artifact-sa.yml are used in post-run
to collect zuul artifacts.

Both are defined in multinode and standalone CentOS 8 base jobs.

While doing Zuul job reparenting, We found that It cannot be used
in different jobs defined in downstream or RDO. As zuul looks for
playbook in the project where zuul jobs are defined.

In order to reuse it in downstream and RDO, we are converting it
into role and call it in starting as a part of post.yaml playbook.

Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ibae7eaa6e6e91c88ac233c8fd52550e89bf2defc
'}, {'created': '2022-03-07 15:29:11.000000000', 'message': 'Added tripleo-ci-post ansible role

playbooks/tripleo-ci/post-artifact-mult.yml and
playbooks/tripleo-ci/post-artifact-sa.yml are used in post-run

commit_message:
Added tripleo-ci-post ansible role

playbooks/tripleo-ci/post-artifact-mult.yml and
playbooks/tripleo-ci/post-artifact-sa.yml are used in post-run
to collect zuul artifacts.

Both are defined in multinode and standalone CentOS 8 base jobs.

While doing Zuul job reparenting, We found that It cannot be used
in different jobs defined in downstream or RDO. As zuul looks for
playbook in the project where zuul jobs are defined.

In order to reuse it in downstream and RDO, we are converting it
into role and call it in starting as a part of post.yaml playbook.

It also removes it from post-run.

Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ibae7eaa6e6e91c88ac233c8fd52550e89bf2defc

commit_message:
Add missing image build job post-run playbook part

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ci/+/832278
adds the standard job definition for containers and Image base job.

But in tripleo-ci-base-images-standard job, post-run part got
missed while copying. It adds the same to unblock
the downstream image build job restructuring.

Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I42d085b2f86bf97bcf39499edfe65dafe6ca5f31

commit_message:
Fix usageState of VNF package update

A VNF package can be associated with multiple VNF instances.
Previously when a VNF instance is deleted, usageState of the
associated VNF package is changed to 'NOT_IN_USE' unconditionally.
It is not correct if there is another VNF instance associated
same VNF package.
This patch fixes to change usageState to 'NOT_IN_USE' only if
there is no VNF instance associated the VNF Package.

Closes-Bug: #1963858
Change-Id: Ib15ffd89d057079a50e6ebc62378e0d83086b107

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/yoga

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/yoga branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Ic00c9d4013330127b142925e725f1cc0842c425f

commit_message:
oslo_config_validator: Defaulting config_invalidations to empty list

When a node doesn't have anything to validate, the config invalidation
fails, reporting a false negative.

Related: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/2047328
Change-Id: I77e0c4568ecca2638aaa880369b9dec0eb5d1599
(cherry picked from commit ebcab3dbe93f80749de02f92d0bf1a57b18e45f8)
(cherry picked from commit c98827fc46df3cff402eb002049d533a10c8a74c)

commit_message:
Fix context unit test

This was caused by the bump of oslo.context to 4.1.0 [1], which includes
removal of the deprecated argument tenant from RequestContext [2].

Replace tenant key in the context object by project_id to fix the lower
constraints job, which is still using oslo.context 2.22.0.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/requirements/+/829599
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/oslo.context/+/815938

Change-Id: I281ffa4f6fc29c691da48a792bc203818e334d9d

revisions:
[{'created': '2022-02-07 19:09:50.000000000', 'message': 'Fix up order of charm and payload upgrades

Improve the information on order lists for both charm and
payload upgrades.

Add the following charms to the charms order:

* manila-ganesha
* octavia

Add the following charm to the payload order:

* manila-ganesha

The manila-generic alpha charm was erroneously included
in both lists. Remove it.

Add a note to both pages stating that only stable charms
are currently considered.

On the charms page it is mentioned that the given order is
based on internal testing because it is also stated that
order is irrelevant. The sentence was dropped from the
payload page because the order is not irrelevant.

Closes-Bug: #1959632
Change-Id: I3a71c3ed1a1d5c0463db8ca3ec598cd53aedf3c7
'}]
commit_message:
Fix up order of charm and payload upgrades

Improve the information on order lists for both charm and
payload upgrades.

Add the following charms to the charms order:

* manila-ganesha
* octavia

Add the following charm to the payload order:

* manila-ganesha

The manila-generic alpha charm was erroneously included
in both lists. Remove it.

Add a note to both pages stating that only stable charms
are currently considered.

On the charms page it is mentioned that the given order is
based on internal testing because it is also stated that
order is irrelevant. The sentence was dropped from the
payload page because the order is not irrelevant.

Closes-Bug: #1959632
Change-Id: I3a71c3ed1a1d5c0463db8ca3ec598cd53aedf3c7

commit_message:
Update Arne email id

governance tooling use gerrit account query to check the
vote count (https://review.opendev.org/accounts/<email>)
and it seems that is case sensitive. It cannot find the
account for Arne as email listed in members file is not
in upper letters what gerrit has.

Change-Id: Ie063a9e239ac482e9dc3e4ecf2f60c13b2a700b1

'}, {'created': '2021-10-08 01:17:14.000000000', 'message': 'Fix duplicate entry error in VNF Package upload

In the current implementation, when we try to upload a VNF package which
has been uploaded and deleted once before, "Duplicate entry" error
occurs and it fails to be onboarded.

This problem happens because VNFD table uses ``vnfd id`` as its primary
key and does not delete a record even if a corresponding VNF package is
deleted.

Although legacy DB is going to be deleted, the patch is not merged at
this time [1].  Thus, this patch modifies the conductor server to simply
delete records from VNFD table.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tacker/+/763955

commit_message:
Fix duplicate entry error in VNF Package upload

In the current implementation, when we try to upload a VNF package which
has been uploaded and deleted once before, "Duplicate entry" error
occurs and it fails to be onboarded.

This problem happens because VNFD table uses ``vnfd id`` as its primary
key and does not delete a record even if a corresponding VNF package is
deleted.

Although legacy DB is going to be deleted, the patch is not merged at
this time [1]. Thus, this patch modifies the conductor server to simply
delete records from VNFD table.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tacker/+/763955

Change-Id: I21316cd7b17f85d292a18a44c891f3193ca418ed
Closes-bug: #1920105
Signed-off-by: Hiromu Asahina <hiromu.asahina.az@hco.ntt.co.jp>

commit_message:
db: Add tests to ensure we keep migrations in sync

Our database migrations were previously out of sync with the models
used. These issues are now resolved, but we want to prevent this
happening again. Add tests to do just that. oslo.db does most of the
heavy lifting here and we simply use the tests that this provides.

Change-Id: Iad51e8c4c78f9ed813cb44ad4e13d0d1c84cfc40
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Remove HA page

This page is being moved to the CG (charm-guide) as the
long-term vision of the CDG (deploy-guide) is to focus
solely on the deployment of Charmed OpenStack.

Redirects were put in place as a consequence.

This PR also aids in other doc efforts taking place in
the CG.

Drive-by: Repair a link on the index page that points
          to the Ceph documentation.

Depends-On: Iae5cdfad42b6775a053a5de8d8e73def318d277d
Change-Id: I95ce35b577343864eadaffa2398047455dc4f868

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-12-14 02:22:22.000000000', 'message': 'Refactor Fake Grant for Simulate NFVO

Currently, the fake_grant.py file used to simulate Response
for GrantRequest cannot return the correct zone-related content
according to the Request and cannot exist as a simulated NFVO
during manual testing.

This refactoring mainly makes the following changes to fake_grant.py.
    1. Append the handling of the contents of the zone so that the
    code can return the corresponding zone result based on the
    placementConstraints in RequestBody.
    2. Modify the original default data of image and flavor, but get
    the result defined in VNFD as the return value.
    3. Add the fake_grant_server.py file, which can be started
    during manual testing and return the Response of GrantRequest
    as simulated NFVO.

Change-Id: I322bbeee81db5db199fb23c7e9115925fd04d344

'}, {'created': '2022-03-08 12:32:08.000000000', 'message': 'Refactor Fake Grant for Simulate NFVO

Currently, the fake_grant.py file used to simulate Response
for GrantRequest cannot return the correct zone-related content
according to the Request and cannot exist as a simulated NFVO
during manual testing.

This refactoring mainly makes the following changes to fake_grant.py.
    1. Append the handling of the contents of the zone so that the
    code can return the corresponding zone result based on the
    placementConstraints in RequestBody.
    2. Modify the original default data of image and flavor, but get
    the result defined in VNFD as the return value.
    3. Add the fake_grant_server.py file, which can be started
    during manual testing and return the Response of GrantRequest
    as simulated NFVO.

Change-Id: I322bbeee81db5db199fb23c7e9115925fd04d344
'}]
commit_message:
Refactor Fake Grant for Simulate NFVO

Currently, the fake_grant.py file used to simulate Response
for GrantRequest cannot return the correct zone-related content
according to the Request and cannot exist as a simulated NFVO
during manual testing.

This refactoring mainly makes the following changes to fake_grant.py.
    1. Append the handling of the contents of the zone so that the
    code can return the corresponding zone result based on the
    placementConstraints in RequestBody.
    2. Modify the original default data of image and flavor, but get
    the result defined in VNFD as the return value.
    3. Add the fake_grant_server.py file, which can be started
    during manual testing and return the Response of GrantRequest
    as simulated NFVO.

Change-Id: I322bbeee81db5db199fb23c7e9115925fd04d344

commit_message:
(WIP) Pod support: Download pod_config

Adds downloading the pod_config output from the RoleData stack output to
the config-download directory. As get_file is used on the
tripleo-heat-templates side to read in the pod YAML's into the service
templates which results in a string value, the download code takes care
of converting the string back to a YAML document.

Change-Id: I89695d622122fd9cc48a8de094f63ebd67ffa7d9
Signed-off-by: James Slagle <jslagle@redhat.com>

there are VMs to migrate.

commit_message:
Ensure migrate all the VMs before upgrade the compute

Currently, there is one case that escape from the nest if/else
statements. When there are instances to migrate and there is no
DO_NO_MIGRATE_IDs, there was returing 0.

This patch fixed that and makes the script return 1, because
there are VMs to migrate.

This patch also removed the second "host_quiesced" called, as
it was previously executed on the while statement.

Co-authored-by: Daniel Mats Niklas Bengtsson <dbengt@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Idfb9899cc9a599bff2e335c74edd7ee4f74e8c06
(cherry picked from commit 305d9fb0d830fdd98b7dc4c4bd92b833ed5916d4)

commit_message:
Import HA page from the CDG

The HA page needs to be moved from the deploy-guide.

Cascading dependencies:

This PR is needed at this time because another doc
effort (doc criteria PR) references the charm README
template (another dependent PR) that in turn
references the HA page as well as gives the impression
that the HA page should not be in the CDG.

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/yoga

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/yoga branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I4c0eed5168831a99d5374d0ced1c33c8bb38fc34

subject: Avoid using 'foo' as invalid JSON test data
messages: [{'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2022-03-06 20:34:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 23851, 'date': '2022-03-08 17:40:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2022-03-06 20:34:36.000000000', 'message': "Avoid using 'foo' as invalid JSON test data

Downstream test environments appear to have a file called 'foo' either
created out-of-band, or created by tests executed in a
non-deterministic order.

This changes the test data to very invalid json which is unlikely to
be a filename, ensuring the expected codepath is tested.

Change-Id: I88ed81337c6e2d724b3cf4ddf90e0d60fa052d1c
(cherry picked from commit 59df415bbf66296fcc4a9abcfca6c764b7538e21)
"}]
commit_message:
Avoid using 'foo' as invalid JSON test data

Downstream test environments appear to have a file called 'foo' either
created out-of-band, or created by tests executed in a
non-deterministic order.

This changes the test data to very invalid json which is unlikely to
be a filename, ensuring the expected codepath is tested.

Change-Id: I88ed81337c6e2d724b3cf4ddf90e0d60fa052d1c
(cherry picked from commit 59df415bbf66296fcc4a9abcfca6c764b7538e21)

commit_message:
Avoid using 'foo' as invalid JSON test data

Downstream test environments appear to have a file called 'foo' either
created out-of-band, or created by tests executed in a
non-deterministic order.

This changes the test data to very invalid json which is unlikely to
be a filename, ensuring the expected codepath is tested.

(cherry picked from commit 59df415bbf66296fcc4a9abcfca6c764b7538e21)

commit_message:
Validate path when passing a config-drive

Currently when --config-drive should point to a file or directory the
command silently uses the path as a configdrive if this file/directory
does not exist.

This is not easily understandable for the user as no error message appears.

Change-Id: I92d8ce2a61f459ce14335bfb05424dc883dbc4d1
(cherry picked from commit bd76a5766c76727109d67020696804efafea73f1)

commit_message:
Fix detection of member operating status DRAIN

When querying the status from HAProxy all values get read as
strings. Because the check wrongly assumed integer type values
it never detected the DRAIN status.

Story: 2009817
Task: 44389

Change-Id: If7d68c95173b8da66050659d1fb86225880dafdd
(cherry picked from commit d350f0908f5111cf2791feed9ea83219c8b984fb)

commit_message:
Support SB OVSDB connections to non-leader servers

Since SB connections are read-mostly, they should be able to
connect to non-leader clustered ovsdb servers. This will allow
distributing the SB connections for ovn neutron-api and metadta
workers.

Conflict:
    neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_driver/ovsdb/ovsdb_monitor.py

Change-Id: I7442170d015f195a5430e71567fbc7d67b81d385
(cherry picked from commit 10f23398ce43a666c17feeef7c1b516ce3afddff)

subject: Bump pod exec timeout in Service connectivity tests
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 4727, 'name': 'Itzik Brown', 'email': 'itzikb@redhat.com', 'username': 'itzikb1'}, {'_account_id': 11600, 'name': 'Micha≈Ç Dulko', 'email': 'mdulko@redhat.com', 'username': 'dulek'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23567, 'name': 'Luis Tomas Bolivar', 'email': 'ltomasbo@redhat.com', 'username': 'ltomasbo'}, {'_account_id': 27032, 'name': 'Maysa de Macedo Souza', 'email': 'maysa.macedo95@gmail.com', 'username': 'maysa'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2022-03-04 14:03:23.000000000', 'message': "Bump pod exec timeout in Service connectivity tests

When testing UDP connectivity to a Service we're using ncat with `-w 5`
option. This sets the connectivity timeout to that value. However our
`exec_command_in_pod()` method is run in async mode and defaults timeout
to wait for completion to just 2 seconds. This is in conflict and if for
some reason UDP server on the pod is slow, will terminate the request
before it's completed, leaving empty stdout but also stderr, so that we
won't even log the error response.

This commit bumps that timeout to 10 seconds to give the pod time to
actually response. I decided to bump it for all the checks as we've seen
this happening with SCTP tests as well and I expect this might have the
same cause.

Change-Id: I303b87d01496cf7353b2b8b699e0dce598e032ab
"}]
commit_message:
Bump pod exec timeout in Service connectivity tests

When testing UDP connectivity to a Service we're using ncat with `-w 5`
option. This sets the connectivity timeout to that value. However our
`exec_command_in_pod()` method is run in async mode and defaults timeout
to wait for completion to just 2 seconds. This is in conflict and if for
some reason UDP server on the pod is slow, will terminate the request
before it's completed, leaving empty stdout but also stderr, so that we
won't even log the error response.

This commit bumps that timeout to 10 seconds to give the pod time to
actually response. I decided to bump it for all the checks as we've seen
this happening with SCTP tests as well and I expect this might have the
same cause.

Change-Id: I303b87d01496cf7353b2b8b699e0dce598e032ab

commit_message:
Remove policy overrides page

This page is being moved to the CG (charm-guide) as the
long-term vision of the CDG (deploy-guide) is to focus
solely on the deployment of Charmed OpenStack.

Redirects were put in place as a consequence.

This PR also aids in other doc efforts taking place in
the CG.

Drive-by: Fix existing redirects (s/howto/admin)

Depends-On: Ib3d02d716bdad0bce52ed72b7528ad1ccb301bb3
Change-Id: Id61ea10b30cff0f10a09b32b66b693dd9b8ab6bb

commit_message:
Remove create_server_snapshot method

As tempest.scenario.manager was announced stable interface in Tempest 27.0.0[1] it can be now reused in plugins.

Replaced methods:
	* create_server_snapshot

Etherpad concerning this effort:
https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/tempest-scenario-manager-cleanup

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/tempest/v27.0.0.html#release-notes-27-0-0

Change-Id: I559fafba4d354f759bef69c0bdd9c3681f27d8c7

revisions:
[{'created': '2022-03-08 11:54:35.000000000', 'message': "CI: Cleanup what we gather from K8s

Seems like the set of resources we gather from K8s for CI gates
debugging purposes was outdated. This commit updates it to make sure
we're also getting NPs and KLBs, while removing Ingress, KuryrNet and
KuryrNetPolicy that are obsolete today.

Besides that KuryrNet and KuryrNetPolicy CRD definitions are removed as
we're not using them for a long time now.

Change-Id: Ia7ecd8f79b6ac0a8172cf108e228e2ea1cb7a0d5
"}]
commit_message:
CI: Cleanup what we gather from K8s

Seems like the set of resources we gather from K8s for CI gates
debugging purposes was outdated. This commit updates it to make sure
we're also getting NPs and KLBs, while removing Ingress, KuryrNet and
KuryrNetPolicy that are obsolete today.

Besides that KuryrNet and KuryrNetPolicy CRD definitions are removed as
we're not using them for a long time now.

Change-Id: Ia7ecd8f79b6ac0a8172cf108e228e2ea1cb7a0d5

subject: Fix ping_results_*.log file name
messages: [{'account_id': 33080, 'date': '2022-03-08 08:28:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11090, 'date': '2022-03-08 14:15:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2022-03-08 08:28:58.000000000', 'message': "Fix ping_results_*.log file name

Fixes ping_results_*.log file name by adding %S to date format string in
order to make it more specific. This solves problem which occurs when
next update steps start at the same hour and minute and writes to the
same file. The problem showed up when new update step 'Update OVN
controllers.' was introduced.[1]

[1]https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-upgrade/+/830743

Change-Id: I78ee113f16897c45fb03f0c9561685ffb531a4e4
(cherry picked from commit 1bbaeef5129d65ac9659531611449c2994821c01)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix ping_results_*.log file name

Fixes ping_results_*.log file name by adding %S to date format string in
order to make it more specific. This solves problem which occurs when
next update steps start at the same hour and minute and writes to the
same file. The problem showed up when new update step 'Update OVN
controllers.' was introduced.[1]

[1]https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-upgrade/+/830743

Change-Id: I78ee113f16897c45fb03f0c9561685ffb531a4e4
(cherry picked from commit 1bbaeef5129d65ac9659531611449c2994821c01)

subject: Redefining the irrelevant files list to ensure execution graph stability
messages: [{'account_id': 32926, 'date': '2022-03-04 13:37:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 16515, 'date': '2022-03-07 20:51:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 8449, 'date': '2022-03-08 08:19:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2\n\n(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 16515, 'date': '2022-03-08 13:39:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2022-03-04 13:37:13.000000000', 'message': 'Redefining the irrelevant files list to ensure execution graph stability

The default irrelevant file definition was leading
to potential edge case when jobs were requested, with their dependencies
being skipped at the same time.
This caused discontinuity of the execution graph and immediety failure of
the check pipeline.

This patch resolves the issue by redefining the irrelevant files list
for selected jobs.

Signed-off-by: Jiri Podivin <jpodivin@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I3585ad40741db85845fab86987045c1ac10eb084
'}]
commit_message:
Redefining the irrelevant files list to ensure execution graph stability

The default irrelevant file definition was leading
to potential edge case when jobs were requested, with their dependencies
being skipped at the same time.
This caused discontinuity of the execution graph and immediety failure of
the check pipeline.

This patch resolves the issue by redefining the irrelevant files list
for selected jobs.

Signed-off-by: Jiri Podivin <jpodivin@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I3585ad40741db85845fab86987045c1ac10eb084

Podman.

commit_message:

commit_message:
Make cron logfile minsize,maxsize configurable

This patch is moving minsize and maxsize logrotate
options to defaults and use them in template.

Change-Id: Ic2dfc747faedef8a7a4bc5e61db7c0cb5bf93e88

revisions:
[{'created': '2022-02-22 17:00:11.000000000', 'message': "Temporarily disable stable jobs

We have multiple CI stability issues going on at the moment.  In order
to be able to merge master fixes, we need to disable broken stable jobs.
Once kuryr-tempest-plugin is stabilized we should be able to merge fixes
to the stable jobs and then we'll be able to revert this patch and make
them voting again.

Change-Id: I5e8fccec80b1a5593e9e32f8dadf8bc220d0424a
"}]
commit_message:
Temporarily disable stable jobs

We have multiple CI stability issues going on at the moment.  In order
to be able to merge master fixes, we need to disable broken stable jobs.
Once kuryr-tempest-plugin is stabilized we should be able to merge fixes
to the stable jobs and then we'll be able to revert this patch and make
them voting again.

Change-Id: I5e8fccec80b1a5593e9e32f8dadf8bc220d0424a

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/yoga branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

'}]
commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/yoga

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/yoga branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Ie5603ca5d04c1952aab80b66610d27816dcb641a

commit_message:
Remove domain equivalence check

The check that the IDM domain matches the overcloud domain
is no longer required.  We support scenarios where these differ.

It would be useful to have some DNS checks to confirm the ability
to reach both domains, but that can be done in a subsequent change.

Change-Id: If670d7a1fb3fb45fc198a3484de9a953c822bf3c

commit_message:
oslo_config_validator: Defaulting config_invalidations to empty list

When a node doesn't have anything to validate, the config invalidation
fails, reporting a false negative.

Related: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/2047328
Change-Id: I77e0c4568ecca2638aaa880369b9dec0eb5d1599
(cherry picked from commit ebcab3dbe93f80749de02f92d0bf1a57b18e45f8)
(cherry picked from commit c98827fc46df3cff402eb002049d533a10c8a74c)
(cherry picked from commit c2aafdd505724bcf923cc7c53be13f051b0fc8d1)
(cherry picked from commit d37148f197c61ba5761708259f868c43c6195013)

Currently /etc/openldap is bind-mounted by keystone containers
with ro flag so it should be excluded from config files generaed
by puppet.

Closes-Bug: #1960781
Change-Id: I8027b829e6b5aebfcd36f5025bb9c848cc96ce3f
(cherry picked from commit daa48254ebbc1b107ec2b382355209c256dbea48)

commit_message:
Exclude /etc/openldap to avoid overriding ro file

Currently /etc/openldap is bind-mounted by keystone containers
with ro flag so it should be excluded from config files generaed
by puppet.

Closes-Bug: #1960781
Change-Id: I8027b829e6b5aebfcd36f5025bb9c848cc96ce3f
(cherry picked from commit daa48254ebbc1b107ec2b382355209c256dbea48)

commit_message:
Add Python 3 only classifier

Python 2 support was removed during Ussuri cycle. This change adds
the classifier to clearly state that only Python 3 is supported.

Change-Id: I51552cadaed82b29dcd10043ba23a0682e549156

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/yoga

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/yoga branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I14d14eb8e316126ddab9a218f1eb8579918317d7

commit_message:
Update python testing classifier

Yoga testing runtime[1] has been updated to add py39
testing as voting. Unit tests update are handled by the
job template change in openstack-zuul-job

- https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-zuul-jobs/+/820286

this commit updates the classifier in setup.cfg file.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/yoga.html

Change-Id: I746c8b70dd41c0a0c929034c6c7fd935e3cc01a4

commit_message:
Update master for stable/yoga

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/yoga.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/yoga.

Sem-Ver: feature
Change-Id: I35de33c2f540ceb76b0b12da5373545c15306f6d

commit_message:
db: Move utility methods to top of file

This helps distinguish them from the actual DB API methods that we'd use
to e.g. populate objects and will simplify the merging of 'nova.db.api'
and 'nova.db.sqlalchemy.api'.

Change-Id: I5f7a8359bddb3cb9951ef6f9e80243a61e5374aa
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/yoga branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

'}]
commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/yoga

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/yoga branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Ibf0011d93c308902671f691a4ef411a653aa3821

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/yoga

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/yoga branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I5f736b1582b8817150229e5f94eb42bc0578f22a

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/yoga.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/yoga.

Sem-Ver: feature
Change-Id: I4f89c2cfa951117c832498a17daeb92b4ce8c70f
'}]
commit_message:
Update master for stable/yoga

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/yoga.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/yoga.

Sem-Ver: feature
Change-Id: I4f89c2cfa951117c832498a17daeb92b4ce8c70f

commit_message:
Add Python3 zed unit tests

This is an automatically generated patch to ensure unit testing
is in place for all the of the tested runtimes for zed.

See also the PTI in governance [1].

[1]: https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/project-testing-interface.html

Change-Id: I4a8a4602b7c671a623358efbe95e434a2bd62f33

docs: Remove unnecessary 'blockstorage-' prefix

These are in the cinder doc tree so of course they're block
storage-related.

Change-Id: Ic1950ff89021a89de397619eef17f8100eb3d847
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

commit_message:
db: Enable auto-generation of database migrations

Alembic does lots of new things. Provide docs for how to use this. This
doesn't actually work that well at the moment because it appears our
database migrations are not in sync with the models. Those issues will
have to be resolved separately.

Change-Id: I6645ca951114b94ce9ed5a83e5e11d53879a7cd5
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/yoga.

Sem-Ver: feature
Change-Id: I3d2b041769c5c14a7d391c223dc499218a937e76

commit_message:
Update master for stable/yoga

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/yoga.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/yoga.

Sem-Ver: feature
Change-Id: I3d2b041769c5c14a7d391c223dc499218a937e76

subject: Leave *_ALL_TABLES to Neutron
messages:
[{'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2021-09-03 01:04:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2021-09-07 07:49:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I replied to Your comment in other patch but I will repeat here too:

I don't agree with that. IMO those constants should be in neutron-lib as they can be used by other projects as well. And also e.g. stadium projects may introduce new constants for own tables there thus having all in single place (similar like api-def) will help to keep it sane. See e.g. BAGPIPE_FLOOD_TO_TUN_BROADCAST constant - this is perfect example of such additional table used by stadium project which is added to that list. And currently to keep this value only for this project it has to be added to neutron so networking-bagpipe project will have to depend on neutron to use it. And our goal should be to reduce such dependencies on neutron for stadium projects and keep them dependent on neutron-lib.
So IMO all those constants (especially those which defines tables) should go to neutron-lib."}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2021-09-07 08:10:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I would discuss first this movement in the Neutron meeting. But in my opinion, this patch is against the purpose of neutron-lib: to have a common place for, as in this case, common variables that provide information to other projects about the OVS OF table distribution.'}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2021-09-07 08:50:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1
> 
> I replied to Your comment in other patch but I will repeat here too:
> 
> I don't agree with that. IMO those constants should be in neutron-lib as they can be used by other projects as well. And also e.g. stadium projects may introduce new constants for own tables there thus having all in single place (similar like api-def) will help to keep it sane. See e.g. BAGPIPE_FLOOD_TO_TUN_BROADCAST constant - this is perfect example of such additional table used by stadium project which is added to that list. And currently to keep this value only for this project it has to be added to neutron so networking-bagpipe project will have to depend on neutron to use it. And our goal should be to reduce such dependencies on neutron for stadium projects and keep them dependent on neutron-lib.
> So IMO all those constants (especially those which defines tables) should go to neutron-lib.

Some comments from https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron-lib/+/804613:


1. Since the qos "VALID_RULE_TYPES" is moved to neutron-lib, we have done some extra works:
  a. copy the new list back, do the Neutron only development works [1].
  b. move the list back to neutron-lib [2]
  c. waiting for neutron-lib to have a new release [3]
  d. update neutron to use constants from neutron-lib  [4]
2. They are going to move the "*_BR_ALL_TABLES" to neutron-lib [5], and doing the same work of rotating Neutron [6]. For these tables, at least two WIP features will have works on these tables [7][8]. So, let them copy these list back to neutron again? Then add a TODO node? It wastes not only developer time, but also code reviewers bandwidth.

Again, since big tent projects are almost retired. If there are constants really needed by sub-projects, it is fine to move those to neutron-lib. Otherwise, leave Neutron used ONLY constants to neutron.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/796363/15/neutron/services/qos/constants.py
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron-lib/+/804378
[3] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/803462
[4] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/804380
[5] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/797121/8/neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/openvswitch/agent/common/constants.py#b1
[6] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/797120/
[7] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron-specs/+/797798/12/specs/xena/node-local-ip.rst@259
[8] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/804213'}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2021-09-07 08:58:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1
> 
> I replied to Your comment in other patch but I will repeat here too:
> 
> I don't agree with that. IMO those constants should be in neutron-lib as they can be used by other projects as well. And also e.g. stadium projects may introduce new constants for own tables there thus having all in single place (similar like api-def) will help to keep it sane. See e.g. BAGPIPE_FLOOD_TO_TUN_BROADCAST constant - this is perfect example of such additional table used by stadium project which is added to that list. And currently to keep this value only for this project it has to be added to neutron so networking-bagpipe project will have to depend on neutron to use it. And our goal should be to reduce such dependencies on neutron for stadium projects and keep them dependent on neutron-lib.
> So IMO all those constants (especially those which defines tables) should go to neutron-lib.

Your case just proves that there is no relationship between two projects for the tables list. Neutron does not handle the flows on the table BAGPIPE_FLOOD_TO_TUN_BROADCAST. And this BAGPIPE_FLOOD_TO_TUN_BROADCAST could not be added to the *_ALL_LIST, because neutron should not toach any flows on these table. Vice versaÔºå bagpipe should not toach any flows belong to Neutron. [1] is the bug which indicates that neutron will clean some flows which is for bagpipe.

So, this _ALL_LIST is for neutron only. Any projects want similar list, construct it in their own place.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/networking-bagpipe/+bug/1919104"}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2021-09-07 09:09:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1
> 
> I would discuss first this movement in the Neutron meeting. But in my opinion, this patch is against the purpose of neutron-lib: to have a common place for, as in this case, common variables that provide information to other projects about the OVS OF table distribution.

Any single table's name and number is fine to placed in neutron-lib. But these *_ALL_TABLEs lists are not common used. The list is a combination or deduction. It has project uniqueness. Neutron uses it to clean stale flows during agent restart. No other purpose. So, this list breaks key workd "common" the purpose of neutron-lib. It's not common.'}, {'account_id': 8313, 'date': '2021-09-07 12:19:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I think it brings us to a good discussion to have a common denominator regarding what to move to neutron-lib and what not.
* The original goal was to have all constants & common things in neutron-lib, but this example from Liu is only used by Neutron (now).
* The need to have released neutron-lib for changes with neutron-lib dependency makes the development more time consuming, and hard for newcomers.
* I personally like the idea to have related things in one place, like INT_BR_ALL_TABLES next to table constants (BASE_EGRESS_TABLE, RULES_EGRESS_TABLE....)

So personally I am more on the side to have INT_BR_ALL_TABLES in neutron-lib, but I see the pain points of it as well'}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2021-09-07 14:03:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2021-09-07 15:04:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Change-Id: Iaa74b01ee266e0d0c8c15e5079145087b9b52339
'}, {'created': '2021-09-07 14:03:54.000000000', 'message': 'Leave *_ALL_TABLES to Neutron

Leave those constants back to neutron which are only used
by Neutron. And prevent to do some extra works that which
is copying these list back to Neutron again.

Any other project should not add its own new table to this
*_ALL_LIST, because neutron should not toach any flows on
these table. Vice versa, other projects should not touch
any flows (tables) belong to Neutron.

Any single table's name and number is fine to placed in
neutron-lib. But these *_ALL_TABLEs lists are not common
used. The list is a combination or deduction. It has
project uniqueness. Neutron uses it to clean stale flows
during agent restart. No other purpose. So, this list
breaks key word "common" the purpose of neutron-lib.
It's not common used.

Many times new feature is going to added to neutron,
it will need to wait for neutron-lib to release. Then
updating the neutron requirements, rotating the neutron
patch, and wating... Since the big tent of networking
projects are mostly going to retired, like networking-vpn,
fwaas, lbaas and so on, IMO, we can move the neutron-lib
related change to neutron first. If some sub-project is
really wants this/that constants or exceptions, do it
that time. I don't think a new feature is directly relied
on. So we can make the neutron develop cycle more smoothly.
For new hands of Neutron, this is something like to set
barriers for new neutron developers. They want to contribute
to Neutron, but their patiences are going to be consumed by
the complex and tedious waiting/rotating/updating processes.

Here are some examples:
1. Since the qos "VALID_RULE_TYPES" is moved to neutron-lib,
  we have done some extra works:
  a. copy the new list back, do the Neutron only development works [1].
  b. move the list back to neutron-lib [2]
  c. waiting for neutron-lib to have a new release [3]
  d. update neutron to use constants from neutron-lib  [4]
2. They are going to move the "*_BR_ALL_TABLES" to neutron-lib [5],
  and doing the same work of rotating Neutron [6]. For these tables,
  at least two WIP features will have works on these tables [7][8].
  So, let them copy these list back to neutron again? Then add a
  TODO node? It wastes not only developer time, but also code

Again, since big tent projects are almost retired. If there are
constants really needed by sub-projects, it is fine to move
those to neutron-lib. Otherwise, leave Neutron used ONLY constants
to neutron.

commit_message:
Leave *_ALL_TABLES to Neutron

Leave those constants back to neutron which are only used
by Neutron. And prevent to do some extra works that which
is copying these list back to Neutron again.

Any other project should not add its own new table to this
*_ALL_LIST, because neutron should not toach any flows on
these table. Vice versa, other projects should not touch
any flows (tables) belong to Neutron.

Any single table's name and number is fine to placed in
neutron-lib. But these *_ALL_TABLEs lists are not common
used. The list is a combination or deduction. It has
project uniqueness. Neutron uses it to clean stale flows
during agent restart. No other purpose. So, this list
breaks key word "common" the purpose of neutron-lib.
It's not common used.

Many times new feature is going to added to neutron,
it will need to wait for neutron-lib to release. Then
updating the neutron requirements, rotating the neutron
patch, and wating... Since the big tent of networking
projects are mostly going to retired, like networking-vpn,
fwaas, lbaas and so on, IMO, we can move the neutron-lib
related change to neutron first. If some sub-project is
really wants this/that constants or exceptions, do it
that time. I don't think a new feature is directly relied
on. So we can make the neutron develop cycle more smoothly.
For new hands of Neutron, this is something like to set
barriers for new neutron developers. They want to contribute
to Neutron, but their patiences are going to be consumed by
the complex and tedious waiting/rotating/updating processes.

Here are some examples:
1. Since the qos "VALID_RULE_TYPES" is moved to neutron-lib,
  we have done some extra works:
  a. copy the new list back, do the Neutron only development works [1].
  b. move the list back to neutron-lib [2]
  c. waiting for neutron-lib to have a new release [3]
  d. update neutron to use constants from neutron-lib  [4]
2. They are going to move the "*_BR_ALL_TABLES" to neutron-lib [5],
  and doing the same work of rotating Neutron [6]. For these tables,
  at least two WIP features will have works on these tables [7][8].
  So, let them copy these list back to neutron again? Then add a
  TODO node? It wastes not only developer time, but also code
  reviewers bandwidth.

Again, since big tent projects are almost retired. If there are
constants really needed by sub-projects, it is fine to move
those to neutron-lib. Otherwise, leave Neutron used ONLY constants
to neutron.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/796363/15/neutron/services/qos/constants.py
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron-lib/+/804378
[3] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/803462
[4] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/804380
[5] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/797121/8/neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/openvswitch/agent/common/constants.py#b1
[6] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/797120/
[7] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron-specs/+/797798/12/specs/xena/node-local-ip.rst@259
[8] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/804213

Change-Id: Iaa74b01ee266e0d0c8c15e5079145087b9b52339

[{'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2021-08-27 08:26:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2021-08-27 10:04:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Build succeeded.

- neutron http://cloudbase-ci.com/neutron/806329/1 : SUCCESS in 1h 37m 19s'}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2021-08-27 14:11:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Build succeeded.

- neutron http://cloudbase-ci.com/neutron/806329/1 : SUCCESS in 1h 36m 19s'}, {'account_id': 33145, 'date': '2021-08-30 02:01:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I agree adding greenthread pool will speed up neutron-openvswitch-agent and allow it can deal with more tasks with higher performance as it is distributed on each compute node.

What I concern is that the bottleneck in large scale scenario is neutron server rather than neutron-openvswitch-agent. In deployment with 1000 or 2000 nodes, neutron-server may busy with normal heart-beat messages. Will these change break the balance and lead RPC message stuck on neutron-server side and cause rpc timeout?

Base on our observation in 1500 node scenario, we need to adjust memory,cpu, api/rpc worker numbers according to actual business load. And this change may heavy the load especially in large quantity of VM creating or migrating scenario. 

May I know what is your observation in such scenario and what is your consideration?'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2021-08-30 08:29:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> I agree adding greenthread pool will speed up neutron-openvswitch-agent and allow it can deal with more tasks with higher performance as it is distributed on each compute node.
> 
> What I concern is that the bottleneck in large scale scenario is neutron server rather than neutron-openvswitch-agent. In deployment with 1000 or 2000 nodes, neutron-server may busy with normal heart-beat messages. Will these change break the balance and lead RPC message stuck on neutron-server side and cause rpc timeout?
> 
> Base on our observation in 1500 node scenario, we need to adjust memory,cpu, api/rpc worker numbers according to actual business load. And this change may heavy the load especially in large quantity of VM creating or migrating scenario. 
> 
> May I know what is your observation in such scenario and what is your consideration?

I second those questions. It seems like this change may speed things up in case when one ovs-agent handles many ports because those messages will be then distrbuted to many neutron-servers but in case when there is many ovs-agents with many ports, it may cause overload on neutron-server side in corner case.
Can You provide more info what issue exactly You are trying to solve and what are the numbers with and without that change?'}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2021-08-30 09:47:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1
> 
> > Patch Set 1:
> > 
> > I agree adding greenthread pool will speed up neutron-openvswitch-agent and allow it can deal with more tasks with higher performance as it is distributed on each compute node.
> > 
> > What I concern is that the bottleneck in large scale scenario is neutron server rather than neutron-openvswitch-agent. In deployment with 1000 or 2000 nodes, neutron-server may busy with normal heart-beat messages. Will these change break the balance and lead RPC message stuck on neutron-server side and cause rpc timeout?

This patch is not related to heart-beat, it's port processing related RPC. Nothing changed on neutron-server side, if something will be stuck in neutron-server side, it will be stuck no matter with or whtout this patch. So if we meet that, report the bug, and fix it independently. This is only on agent side.

> > 
> > Base on our observation in 1500 node scenario, we need to adjust memory,cpu, api/rpc worker numbers according to actual business load. And this change may heavy the load especially in large quantity of VM creating or migrating scenario. 
> > 

With this patch, you will not need to adjust your settings if you are not going to restart 1500 nodes once for all. For VM creating or migrating, the main point should be "how many VM". Please see my summary below.

> > May I know what is your observation in such scenario and what is your consideration?
> 
> I second those questions. It seems like this change may speed things up in case when one ovs-agent handles many ports because those messages will be then distrbuted to many neutron-servers but in case when there is many ovs-agents with many ports, it may cause overload on neutron-server side in corner case.
> Can You provide more info what issue exactly You are trying to solve and what are the numbers with and without that change?

Please consider the problem in transverse and longitudinal views. Transverse problem is how many ports for one ovs-agent hosted (or trying to process). Longitudinal is how many hosts (or nodes, or ovs-agents) are calling this update_device_list RPC concurrently. And there are two cases: 1) agent restart, 2) VM booting storm (ports plug on ovs-bridge). So, after arrangement and combination, these scenarios can be limited to the followings:
1. one agent restart, this this is speeding up the agent restart time. Instead of waiting for the RPC call one by one, this patch make the call steps to 8 threads in concurency mode. It makes the ovs-agent get ready earlier for new ports processing. Assuming one RPC call of update_device_list will consume 1s, step size is 20 ports once, then 1000 ports will be 50 * 1 = 50s without this patch. In concurrency mode, it should be less than 8s.
2. plug 100? 1000? port to one ovs-agent? This is something like ovs-agent restart, this patch helps.
3. restart 100 or 1000 ovs-agents one time? When you have 1000 or more ovs-agents, restart all of them once for all is not practical no matter with or without this patch. The bottleneck is neutron-server DB related action. The pressure is on DB. In real world deployment, it's better to limit the restarting agents to under 50. We tested restart 20, 40, 50 ovs-agents in a shot with this patch, they all were fine to work.
4. plug 100 * (1000 ports/node) or 1000 * (1000 ports/node) on 100 or 1000 ovs-agents? Mission impossible for Neutron, no matter with or without this patch.

Here are some cases which are impossible for Neutron no matter with or without this patch:
1. your neutron-server has a few RPC workers, but you want to serve 1k+, 10K+ or more hosts (ovs-agents).
2. host 1K+Ôºå 10K+ or more ports on one host.
3. restart all your agents one time when your neutron-server has only a few RPC workers.
4. Create 1000+ host * (100+ VMs/host) in a very shot time.
5. Plug 1000+ host * (100+ ports/host) in a very shot time.'}, {'account_id': 33145, 'date': '2021-08-31 01:58:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> > Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1
> > 
> > > Patch Set 1:
> > > 
> > > I agree adding greenthread pool will speed up neutron-openvswitch-agent and allow it can deal with more tasks with higher performance as it is distributed on each compute node.
> > >

In deployment with 1000 or 2000 nodes, neutron-server may busy with normal heart-beat messages. Will these change break the balance and lead RPC message stuck on neutron-server side and cause rpc timeout?
>

Nothing changed on neutron-server side, if something will be stuck in neutron-server side, it will be stuck no matter with or whtout this patch. So if we meet that, report the bug, and fix it independently. This is only on agent side.
> 
> > > 
> > > Base on our observation in 1500 node scenario, we need to adjust memory,cpu, api/rpc worker numbers according to actual business load. And this change may heavy the load especially in large quantity of VM creating or migrating scenario. 
> > > 
>

It seems like this change may speed things up in case when one ovs-agent handles many ports because those messages will be then distrbuted to many neutron-servers but in case when there is many ovs-agents with many ports, it may cause overload on neutron-server side in corner case.
> > Can You provide more info what issue exactly You are trying to solve and what are the numbers with and without that change?
>

Longitudinal is how many hosts (or nodes, or ovs-agents) are calling this update_device_list RPC concurrently. And there are two cases: 1) agent restart, 2) VM booting storm (ports plug on ovs-bridge). So, after arrangement and combination, these scenarios can be limited to the followings:
> 1. one agent restart, this this is speeding up the agent restart time. Instead of waiting for the RPC call one by one, this patch make the call steps to 8 threads in concurency mode. It makes the ovs-agent get ready earlier for new ports processing. Assuming one RPC call of update_device_list will consume 1s, step size is 20 ports once, then 1000 ports will be 50 * 1 = 50s without this patch. In concurrency mode, it should be less than 8s.
> 2. plug 100? 1000? port to one ovs-agent? This is something like ovs-agent restart, this patch helps.
> 3. restart 100 or 1000 ovs-agents one time? When you have 1000 or more ovs-agents, restart all of them once for all is not practical no matter with or without this patch. The bottleneck is neutron-server DB related action. The pressure is on DB. In real world deployment, it's better to limit the restarting agents to under 50. We tested restart 20, 40, 50 ovs-agents in a shot with this patch, they all were fine to work.
> 4. plug 100 * (1000 ports/node) or 1000 * (1000 ports/node) on 100 or 1000 ovs-agents? Mission impossible for Neutron, no matter with or without this patch.
> 
> Here are some cases which are impossible for Neutron no matter with or without this patch:
> 1. your neutron-server has a few RPC workers, but you want to serve 1k+, 10K+ or more hosts (ovs-agents).
> 2. host 1K+Ôºå 10K+ or more ports on one host.
> 3. restart all your agents one time when your neutron-server has only a few RPC workers.
> 4. Create 1000+ host * (100+ VMs/host) in a very shot time.
> 5. Plug 1000+ host * (100+ ports/host) in a very shot time.


I agree with your analyze.

For one single agent restart or small quantity of agent-server synchronization, this change benefit as we speed up the RPC call. OVS agent wait for neutron-servers's response. This will reduce time waiting for response by batch.

What really impact neutron-server is large quantity of RPC call concurrently triggered on OVS agents. Actually it is not agent count but port count matters. For cases listed above, I think one case may be a real case: restart OVS agent.

In product environment, there might be scenario that a region is power off or crashed. If there are HA triggered and VM being migrated to other OVS, or admin start this region manually, large quantity of device update request will be triggered and neutron-server may busy with messages and some of them may timeout if they come too soon.

There is also secenario that we need to change configuraiton for OVS and restart all process. 

Do we hvae recover time comparation between with and without this change in like 1000 nodes?'}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2021-08-31 13:24:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

If I understand correctly this patch is useful in case neutron server often has free RPC workers. Won't it lead to more RPC timeouts if server lacks free RPC workers?"}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2021-09-01 00:53:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

We tested restart 20, 40, 50 ovs-agents in a shot with this patch, they all were fine to work.

> > Here are some cases which are impossible for Neutron no matter with or without this patch:
> > 1. your neutron-server has a few RPC workers, but you want to serve 1k+, 10K+ or more hosts (ovs-agents).
> > 2. host 1K+Ôºå 10K+ or more ports on one host.
> > 3. restart all your agents one time when your neutron-server has only a few RPC workers.
> > 4. Create 1000+ host * (100+ VMs/host) in a very shot time.
> > 5. Plug 1000+ host * (100+ ports/host) in a very shot time.
> 
> 
> I agree with your analyze.
> 
> For one single agent restart or small quantity of agent-server synchronization, this change benefit as we speed up the RPC call. OVS agent wait for neutron-servers's response. This will reduce time waiting for response by batch.
> 
> What really impact neutron-server is large quantity of RPC call concurrently triggered on OVS agents. Actually it is not agent count but port count matters. For cases listed above, I think one case may be a real case: restart OVS agent.
> 
> In product environment, there might be scenario that a region is power off or crashed. If there are HA triggered and VM being migrated to other OVS, or admin start this region manually, large quantity of device update request will be triggered and neutron-server may busy with messages and some of them may timeout if they come too soon.
> 
> There is also secenario that we need to change configuraiton for OVS and restart all process. 
> 
> Do we hvae recover time comparation between with and without this change in like 1000 nodes?

We don't have 1000 nodes. And there is no company can offer you a 1000 nodes environment to test this.'}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2021-09-01 00:55:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1
> 
> (1 comment)
> 
> If I understand correctly this patch is useful in case neutron server often has free RPC workers. Won't it lead to more RPC timeouts if server lacks free RPC workers?

If your neutron-servers are always basy, no matter with or without this patch, your deployment may have encountered problems with resource processing."}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2021-09-01 00:57:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2021-09-01 03:49:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2021-09-01 04:18:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2021-09-01 05:58:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Build succeeded.

- neutron http://cloudbase-ci.com/neutron/806329/2 : SUCCESS in 2h 07m 41s'}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2021-09-01 07:23:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> > Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1
> > 
> > (1 comment)
> > 
> > If I understand correctly this patch is useful in case neutron server often has free RPC workers. Won't it lead to more RPC timeouts if server lacks free RPC workers?
> 
> If your neutron-servers are always basy, no matter with or without this patch, your deployment may have encountered problems with resource processing.

I meant if servers have just enough RPC workers to serve current load - with this patch we need to add more workers, is it correct?"}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2021-09-01 07:59:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 2:
> 
> > Patch Set 1:
> > 
> > > Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1
> > > 
> > > (1 comment)
> > > 
> > > If I understand correctly this patch is useful in case neutron server often has free RPC workers. Won't it lead to more RPC timeouts if server lacks free RPC workers?
> > 
> > If your neutron-servers are always basy, no matter with or without this patch, your deployment may have encountered problems with resource processing.
> 
> I meant if servers have just enough RPC workers to serve current load - with this patch we need to add more workers, is it correct?

Not exactly, It's hard to define "serve current load". All the pressure are based on the number of your compute nodes and the resources (ports, routers, networks etc.). And the pressure are also related to the workload of API requests frequency, agents restart number, ports per host and so on. Each of these variable changes while it may break the status of "serve current load", no matter with or without this patch. And remember we have message queue there, if workers are all busy, the call RPC message may not get consumed. So, in brief, this patch should be fine in normal envrionment with controllable quantity resources and moderate operations. We have this patch in our production environment for almost a year. It works fine.'}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2021-09-01 07:59:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2021-09-01 08:37:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Async call RPC update_device_list

If ovs-agent has many ports, they will be processed
and call update_device_list by a configurable step
size. But these update_device_list calls are run
one by one. This patch add a greethread pool with
size 8 to shot the call in concurrency mode.

Pool size 8 is fixed for now, because we do not want
bring too much pressure on neutron-server side.

Related-Bug: #1813704
Related-Bug: #1938202
Change-Id: Ia77825ca619d3d0c0d0b992975c78c97f470ce52

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/yoga

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/yoga branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Ieb4a21d3a39ef166fc5fe6ca1eba9021f686f513

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/yoga

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/yoga branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I6856dd58d8b80c5e12fa2603abb994149a6288fa

commit_message:
Octavia: Add missing region_name parameters

The region_name parameter is required when Keystone stores information
for multiple region_name. Although multi-domain is not yet supported
by TripleO, the parameter is set globally.

Change-Id: I40e6f811a47a60c6e096508ed743180dfe3be246

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/yoga

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/yoga branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Ie16f61c80e157772ce8024653929bb2803c0b429

commit_message:
Remove _log_console_output, ping_ip_address methods

As tempest.scenario.manager was announced stable interface in Tempest 27.0.0[1] it can be now reused in plugins.

Replaced methods:
	* _log_console_output
	* ping_ip_address

Etherpad concerning this effort:
https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/tempest-scenario-manager-cleanup

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/tempest/v27.0.0.html#release-notes-27-0-0

Change-Id: I1533a2aae3139aa0e81f783049d7fce60931efbe
